thread.title: Gary Neville opens up on Liverpool rivalry: ''I've never been without a police escort!'' - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Gary Neville opens up on Liverpool rivalry: ''I've never been without a police escort!'' - Mirror Online

author: James Whaling
title: Gary Neville opens up on Liverpool rivalry: ''I've never been without a police escort!'' - Mirror Online
text:
Neville picks a coin up off the Anfield pitch (Photo: Getty) Share Get Liverpool FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Manchester United legend Gary Neville has spoken about his own personal rivalry with Liverpool supporters - joking: "I've never been without a police escort!" 
The Red Devils great isn't overly popular on Merseyside owing to his hugely successful playing career at Old Trafford. 
And the rivalry hasn't subsided since he hung up his boots and turned his hand to punditry with Sky Sports. 
Speaking on Soccer AM, Neville said: “I’ve never been to Liverpool in my life - let’s be clear on that. Every time I’ve been to Liverpool I’ve had a police escort - obviously on the coach with United. Neville clashes with Jamie Carragher (Photo: Matthew Peters/Manchester United via Getty) Neville celebrates against Liverpool in 2006 (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
“As a pundit working with Sky - let’s say I have to be there for a three o’clock kick-off - I’m there at 11 in the morning before any one of them turns up. And I’m there until eight o’clock at night when they’ve all gone home. 
“Let them all relax and calm down. They don’t want to see me, do they?” 
Despite his questionable relationship with fans at Anfield, Neville admits matches at Liverpool's ground were the toughest of his career. Neville says games at Anfield were the hardest of his career (Photo: Getty) Read More Jamie Carragher wishes Gary Neville happy birthday by tweeting INCREDIBLY embarrassing photo of him - obviously 
“The hardest game," he added. "The pitch was so tight, the fans were up for it - you knew full well if you won at Anfield it was a massive achievement. 
“You got huge abuse. You took a throw-in on that far side and you got that feeling: there’s going to be a punch on the back of my head here. They can reach me. It’s going to come one day. 
“Either that or a load of beer or… something else." Like us on Facebook
